sp.speaker: Jef.
sp.l: Nay, he's no ſheep-biter.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Didſt thou kill Wallace?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Yes marry did I ſir, if I ſhould be hang'd here before yee, I would not deny it.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How didſt thou kill him? hand to hand?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Hand to hand, as Dog-killers kill dogs, ſo I beat out his brains I'me ſure.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Me thinks, thou ſhouldſt not look him in the face.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: No more I did, I came behind his back & felld him.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Art thou a Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Bolt.
sp.p: I am no gentleman borne, my Father was a poore Fletcher in Grubſtreet, but I am a gentleman by my place.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: What place?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: A Juſtices Clarke, ſir Jeffery Wiſeacres.

sp.speaker: Je.
sp.p: My man, if it pleaſe your Majeſty, an honeſt true Knave.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Give to ſir Wiſeacres Clark an hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: Jef.
sp.l: I thank your grace.

sp.speaker: Bolt.
sp.l: God confound all your foes at the ſame rate.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: But if this Wallace, ſirra, be alive now,
You and your hundred pounds ſhall both be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Bolt.
sp.l: Nay I will be hang'd ere I part from my money,
Who payes, who payes?

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Charge, charge.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: The news brave Clifford.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.p: The daring Scot fuller of inſolence then ſtrength Stand forth to bid us battell.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Throw defiance back downe their throats, and of our Heralds
Northumberland the honor ſhall be thine, tell'um
We come to ſcourge their pride with whips of ſteele,
Their City hath from Iuſtice ſnatch'd her ſword
To ſtrike their Soveraigne, who ha's turn'd the point
Vpon their own breaſts, tell 'em this.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I ſhall. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: Where's noble Bruce?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: I have a meſſage, but tis more honorable, ſent to you too,
The Herald ſaies that Wallace dares ye, his
Spite is all at you, and if your ſpirit be great
As his, you finde him in the reare.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Hang up that wiſeacres, and the fool his man.

sp.speaker: Bolt.
sp.l: My maſter, not me ſir, I have a Recognizance of him
To ſtand betwixt me and the gallows.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: A Kings word muſt be kept, hang 'em both.

sp.speaker: Bolt.
sp.p: One word more good Sir, before I go to this geere,
If a Kings word muſt be kept, why was it not kept, when he gave me the 100. li. wipe out one, I'le wipe out the other.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: That jeſt hath ſav'd your lives, let me ſee you fight to day.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.l: Bravely like Cocks.

sp.speaker: Bolt.
sp.l: Now Wallace look to your coxcombe.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Move on.

div.stage: Enter to them the Scottiſh Army, and are beaten off.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: We have fleſh'd them ſoundly.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: I would not wiſh to meet with braver ſpirits.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Stay, Bruce, what's yonder on the hill?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: They are Collors.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Why do they mangle thus their Armies limbes?
Whats that ſo farre off?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Sure 'tis the Reare, where burns the black brand,
Kindles all this fire, I meane the Traytor Wallace?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What turn'd Coward?
A dogge of ſo good mouth, and ſtand at bay?
If in this heat of fight we breake their ranks,
Preſſe through, and charge that devill, Bruce thy ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: To hell if I can chaſe him.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Charge up ſtrong, harke, brave,
Let now our hands be warriors, not our tongues.

div.stage: Enter the Scottiſh Army, Generall Grimsby, Coming, Mentith.

sp.speaker: A cry within.
sp.l: They flye, they flie.

sp.speaker: Generall.
sp.l: The Engliſh ſhrink, knit all our nerves
And faſten Fortunes offer.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: Keep ſteedy footing, the daye is loſt if you ſtir,
Stirre not, but ſtand the tempeſt.

sp.speaker: Coming.
sp.l: I cry on.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: And I.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: So do not I, this ſtarting backe is but an Engliſh earth-quake, which to duſt, ſhakes rotten towers, but builds the ſound more ſtrong.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Lets on, and dare death in the thickeſt throng.

div.stage: Enter the Engliſh Army, and encompaſſe them.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Did I not give you warning of this whirpoole
For going too farre?

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: We are all dead men, yet fight
So long as legges and Armes laſt.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: In how quicke time
Have we about you built a wall of braſſe?
Had he whom here you call your Generall
A Souldier beene remarkable of great breeding,
And now to be caught with lyme-twigs?

sp.speaker: Generall.
sp.l: Keepe our ground.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: If we muſt fall, fall bravely.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Wound for wound.

sp.speaker: Alarum.
sp.l: Exeunt King and Bruce purſuing the Scots.

div.stage: Clifford, Percy, Grimsby, and Generall ſtay.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.p:
Take breath, I would not have the world rob'd
of two ſuch ſpirits, poaſt to the King, and tell him that the nobleſt Harts of the whole heard are hunted to the toyle,
Aske whether they ſhall fall, or live for gaine.

sp.speaker: Meſſenger.
sp.l: I ſhall.
Charge.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.p: For honours ſake come downe, and ſave thy Countrey.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Whoſe is the day?

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Tis Edwards, come reſcue
Our Generall, and the noble Grimsby.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Who?

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Our Generall and ſtout Grimsby are encloſd
With quick-ſets made of ſteele, come fetch them off,
Or all is loſt.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Is the day loſt?

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Loſt, loſt.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Vnleſſe the day be quite loſt, I'le not ſtirre.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Tis quite loſt.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Why then deſcend amaine, art ſure tis loſt?

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Then wee'le winne it againe.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: How now?

sp.speaker: Meſ.
sp.l: The King proclaimes that man a traytor
That ſaves when he may kill.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: Charge them blacke day,
The Lyon hunts a Lyon for his prey.

div.stage: Enter Wallace and Souldiers, beat off the Engliſh, the Generall, and Grimsby ſlaine.

sp.speaker: Generall.
sp.l: Too late.

sp.speaker: Wall.
sp.l: Why then farewell,
I'le make what haſte I can to follow thee,
Bruce, Bruce, I am here, 'tis Wallace calls thee,
Dares thee.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Tho I nere ſtoopt unto a traitors lure,
I ſcorne thine, why do'ſt thou ſingle me,
Yet turnſt thy weapon downward to the earth?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Lets breathe and talke.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: I'le parly with no traytor but with blows.

sp.speaker: VVal.
sp.l: Ye ſhall have blows your guts full,
I am no traytor.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p: Why 'gainſt thy Soveraigne lifts thou then thy ſword?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: You ſee I lift it not.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Tell Edward ſo thy King.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Longſhancks was never Soveraigne of mine,
Nor ſhall whilſt Bruce lives, Bruce is my Soveraigne,
Thou art but baſtard Engliſh, Scotch true borne,
Th'art made a maſtive 'mongſt a heard of wolves,
To weary thoſe thou ſhouldſt be ſhepheard of.
The fury of the battell now declines,
And take my counſell, though I ſeeme thy foe,
Waſh both thy hands in bloud, and when anon
The Engliſh in their Tents their deeds do boaſt,
Lift thou thy bloudy hands up, and boaſt thine,
And with a ſharpe eye note, but with what ſcorne,
The Engliſh pay thy merit.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: This I'le try.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Dar'ſt thou alone meet me in Glaſco-moore,
And there I'le tell thee more?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Thou haſt no treaſon towards me?

sp.speaker: VVa.
sp.l: Here's my hand,
I am cleare as innocence, had I meant treaſon
Here could I worke it on thee, I have none.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: In Glaſco-moore I'le meet thee, fare thee well.

sp.speaker: VVa.
sp.l: The time.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Some two houres hence.

sp.speaker: VVa.
sp.l: There I will untie
A knot, at which hangs death or Soveraigntie.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: We have ſwet hard to day.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Twas a brave hunting. Bolt offers to lay his Coat under the king.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Sit, ſome wine
Away in the field all fellows, whoſe is this?

sp.speaker: Bolt.
sp.p: It was my Coat at Armes, but now tis yours at legges.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Away, why giveſt thou me a cuſhion?

sp.speaker: Bolt.
sp.p: Becauſe of the two, I take you to be the better man.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: A ſouldiers coat ſhall never be ſo baſe
To lye beneath my heele, th'art in this place
My fellow, and companion, a health to all in England.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Let it come.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: Is not this he that kill'd VVallace?

sp.speaker: Bolt.
sp.l: No ſir, I am onely he that ſaid ſo,
As you ſit, ſo did I lye.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Sirra, where's your maſter?

sp.speaker: Bol.
sp.l: My maſter is ſhot.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How ſhot, where?

sp.speaker: Bol.
sp.l: I'th backe.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Oh he ranne away.

sp.speaker: Bol.
sp.p: No, my Lord, but his harneſſe Cap was blowne off, and he running after it to catch it, was ſhot betweene necke and ſhoulders, and when he ſtood upright he had two heads.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Two heads how?

sp.speaker: Bolt.
sp.p: Yes truly, his own head and the arrow head, it was twenty to one that I had not beene ſhot before him.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why prethee?

sp.speaker: Bolt.
sp.p: Becauſe my Knights name being Wiſeacres, and mine Bolt, and you know a fooles bolt is ſoon ſhot.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.p: He ha's pind the foole upon his maſters ſhoulder very handſomly.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Sirra, go ſeek your maſter, and bid him take order for burying of the dead.

sp.speaker: Bolt.
sp.p: I ſhall Sir, and whilſt he takes order for the burials of the dead, i'le take order for the ſtomacks of the living.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How fought to day our Engliſh?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Bravely.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How the Scots?

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: The pangs of war are like to child-bed throwes
Bitter in ſuffering, but the ſtorme being paſt,
The talk, as of ſcap't ſhipwrack ſweet, doth taſte,
The death of the Scotch Generall went to my heart,
He had in him of man aſmuch as any,
And for ought I think, his bloud was poorly ſold
By his own Countrymen, rather then ſought by us.
Had not the Reare where Wallace did command,
Stood and given ayme, it had bin a day
Bloudy and diſmall, and whoſe hard to ſay,
Sir, you ſhall give me leave to drink a health
To all the valiant Scots.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Clifford, I'le pledge thee, give me my bowle.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Sir, I remembred Wallace in my draught.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I did not, ſo this cup were Wallace Skull,
I'de drinke it full with bloud, for it would ſave
The lives of thouſands.

sp.speaker: Clif
sp.l: I for your Kingdoms would not pledge it ſo.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I would, no matter how a traitor falls.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Percy, ten thouſand Crowns ſhould buy
That traitors head, if I could hav't for money.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: I would give
Twice twenty thouſand Crowns to have his head
On my ſwords point cut from him with this arme,
But how i'th field, nobly, hand to hand, not this ſtraw
To a hangman that ſhould bring it me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Let that paſſe,
Wher's Bruce, our noble Earle of Carrick?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I ſaw him not to day,

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: I did, and ſaw his ſword
Like to a Reapers Sithe, mow down the Scots.
Here he comes.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Brave Armory, a rampant Lion within a field all Gules,
Where haſt been Bruce?

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: Following the execution which we held
Three Engliſh miles in length.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Give him ſome wine, art not thirſty?

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: Yes for Scottiſh bloud, I never ſhall have
Enough on't, the Kings health.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Let come.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: How greedily you Scot drinks his own bloud!

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: If he ſhould taſte your bitterneſſe, 'twere not well.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: What's that ye all laugh'd at?

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Nothing but a jeſt.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: Nay, good Sir tell me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: An idle jeſt, more wine for Bruce.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: No more, I have drunk too much,
Wallace and I did parlee.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: How in words?

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: No Percy, I'me no prater, 'twas with ſwords,
Your laughing jeſt was not at me?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Sir, no.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Bruce would fain quarrell,

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: I ha done ſir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Peace, what Trumpet's that?

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: From the enemy ſure.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Go learn.

sp.speaker: Ruge.
sp.l: I come from Wallace.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: So Sir, what of him?

sp.speaker: Ruge.
sp.l: Thus he ſpeaks.
He bids me dare you to a freſh battaile, by to morrowes ſunne,
Army to Army, troup to troup, he challenges,
Or to ſave bloud, fifty to fifty, ſhall the ſtrife decide,
Or one to one.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: A Herald to the traitor.
Go and thus ſpeak, we bring whips of ſteele,
To ſcourge Rebellion, not to ſtand the braves
Of a baſe daring vaſſall, bid him ere that Sun
Which he calls up be riſen, pay it and ſave
His Country and himſelfe from ruine, charge him on his head,
To make his quick ſubmiſſion; if he ſlow the minutes,
Wee'le proclaime in thunder his and his Countries ruine,
Go be gon, Arme.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Arme, Arme.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: A Land that's ſick at heart muſt take ſharp pils,
For dangerous phyſick beſt cures dangerous ils.

div.head: Actus V.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: As you are a ſouldier, as y' are noble
I charge you and conjure you to unclaſpe
A book in which I am graveld.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: Perhaps I cannot.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: Yes, if you dare you can.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Dare? Clifford dares
Do any thing but wrong and what's not juſt.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: Then tell me ſir, what was that bitter ſcorn,
Which I like poyſon taſted in my wine?

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: I care not if I doe, becauſe I love vertue even in
My enemy, the bowle of wine kiſſing your lip.
Behold, quoth one how eagerly you Scot,
Drinks his own bloud.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: You Scot drinks his own bloud, which Scot?

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Beſt wake ſome Oracle.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: Who brake the jeſt upon me?

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Pray pardon me. Exit Cli

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: The Oracle I'le wake is here, oh Wallace,
I ne're had eyes till now, they were clos'd up
By braving Engliſh, witchcraft drinks his own bloud,
England my ſtepdame take my bitter curſe,
Thy own nails teare thy own bowels, oh my parent
Dear Scotland, I no more will be a goad,
Pricking thy ſides, but if ere I draw a ſword,
It ſhall be double-edg'd with bloud and fire,
To burn and drown this Kingdome and this King.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: My Generall
Charg'd me in privacie to give you theſe.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: Thanks noble Clifford, what did he bid thee ſay?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Nothing but ſo. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: A pair of Spurs, Bruce nere was runaway,
Twelve ſilver pence, oh bitter ſcorn, with Judas,
I have betray'd my Maſter, my dear Country,
And here's the embleme of my treachery,
To haſten to ſome tree, and deſperate die,
Twelve ſterling ſilver pence, ſterling, ha ſterling,
'Tis a limbe of Scotland, ſpurs for flight,
Clifford, i'le thither, comment I wrong or right.

div.stage: Enter Grimsby, Mentith, Coming, Engliſh Herald, and Rouge-croſſe.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Stay noble Grimsby, ere he further paſſe
One of us certifie our Generall,
Perhaps hee'l not admit him to his preſence.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: 'Tis like ſo, ſtay him here, that pains be mine.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Let Ruge-croſſe bring his pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Come agreed.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: You bring from Longſhanks ſome ſtrange meſſage now.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: At leaſt he ſends his Gauntlet.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Gauntlet, no the Engliſh
Fight not two dayes together, but like ſwaggerers,
A fray being made up with a wound or ſo,
The man whoſe throat before ſhould have been cut,
Is a ſworn brother, now we have mall'd your Nation,
Thei'le fawn on us like Spaniels, will they not?

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: And that's thy errand, iſt not?

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.p: Commonly, when Engliſh ſee at cuffs they are too weak, they fall to fiſhing, and then bait the hook with mercie, and the Kings pardon, at which who bites ha's his ſwallowing ſpoiled for ever, there's no Scot but ſcorns to hang his hope on your Kings promiſes, be it nere ſo ſmoothly gilded.

sp.speaker: Herald.
sp.l: He gilds none ſir.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.p: I warrant he would pawn half his Dominions to ſhake hands with Wallace, and be friends.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Had he but him in's Court, he would out-ſhine
His capring gallants, be would dote on him,
As Jupiter did on Ganymede, and make him
His chief Minion.

sp.speaker: Herald.
sp.p: Hee does already ſo really dote upon him, 'tis not yet the age of one houre ſince my Maſter ſware to give ten thouſand Crowns to Scot or Engliſh, that were ſo bold to bring him Wallace's head.

sp.speaker: Ruge.
sp.l: The Engliſh Herald.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Ten thouſand Crowns.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Would make a faire ſhew in our purſes Jack.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: I could pick out five thouſand heads,
That I durſt boldly ſell him at that rate.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Ten thouſand Crowns.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: I and Court wind-falls too,
Some Engliſh Earldome or ſo, here is none but friends,
Should you betray the conference, I care not,
I would deny it, and I would oreſway
Your proofs tho neere ſo maſſie.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: It ſhall not need, beleeve me worthy Mentith.
What here you looke is ſafe.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.p: Shall we earne this Engliſh gold, ten thouſand crownes?

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: My hand.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: They are ours, hee's dead.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: No more, he comes.

sp.speaker: VVal.
sp.l: I am to him no vaſſal, hee's a tyrant,
So tell him, ere his frowne ſhall bend my knee,
This ſhall be hang'd upon the gallow tree,
For my appearance tell him this, I'le dyne
On Chriſtmas day next in his Engliſh Court,
And in his great Hall at Weſtminſter, at's owne boord,
Wee'le drink Scotch healths in his ſtanding cups of gold:
His blacke Iackes hand in hand about his Court
Shall march with our blew bonnets, we'le eate nothing
But what our ſwords ſhall carve, ſo tell his Souldiers,
Wee'le ſit like Lords there whilſt they rayle like ſlaves,
Go with Scotch threats, pay backe your Engliſh braves.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Youle make the Engliſh mad. Exit Herald.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: A brave defiance.

sp.speaker: VVal.
sp.l: Defiance,
Lets mad them more, they ſhall not ſleep to night,
Good Grimsbie beat a drum, let bon-fires ſhine
Through all our army, as if our Tents were burnt,
And we diſlodg'd, but recollect our troops
Into an ordered body, ſome thing wee'le do
To make our Chronicles ſwell with Engliſh rue.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: A Drum, call a Drum. Exit Grimsbie.

sp.speaker: VVa.
sp.l: Oh ſir John Mentith I have crackt the Ice,
To a deſigne, which if it will ſucceed,
England no more ſhall ſtrike, nor Scotland bleed.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Com. Lets be partakers, deare ſir.

sp.speaker: VVal.
sp.p: What will you ſay, if I winne Bruce from the Engliſh?

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: The happieſt day that ever ſhone on Scotland.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: And crowne him King?

sp.speaker: VVal.
sp.l: That's the up-ſhot muſt crowne all, I'm to meet him
Before one houre grow old in Glaſco-moore.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: How meet him?

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: As I am, both come alone, no words to any.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Our lips are ſeal'd.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Will you ride, or go on foot?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: No more, I'le ride.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Wee'le paſſe the wood on foot.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Jack Mentith, I do laugh to think what face,
Longſhancks wil make, when he ſhall heare what gueſts
Will dine with him in's Court on Chriſtmas day.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: What face? he'le kill the Herald ſure.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: Oh! ſome charme for me to be inviſible there, and ſee him.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: For my part, of ten thouſand crownes by this hand,
I do wiſh you there.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: For as many of mine, I ſweare.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Time may come,
In his Exchequer we may ſhare twice that ſumme.

sp.speaker: Wall.
sp.l: Hence, hye you before, keep cloſe in the wood,
Breake forth if you ſpie treaſon, if not, not.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Good. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: Ha, if what thou ſeem'ſt thou art, ſtep forward, ſpeake,
I have fac'd more horrid terror.

sp.speaker: Fryer.
sp.l: Whare do'ſt gang?

sp.speaker: Wall.
sp.l: What's that to thee?

sp.speaker: Fryer.
sp.l: Thouſe not leſt and lang,
Twa wolves will ſuike thy bluide, by the third night,
I charge thy ſawle meete mine, thy death is dight.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Thou art a lying ſpirit.

sp.speaker: Fryer.
sp.l: Bruce byn thy bane,
Gif on thou gang luke not turne backe againe,
Wallace beweere, me thinks it thee ſhould irke,
Mare need haſt thou to ſerve God in the Kirke.

sp.speaker: VVa.
sp.l: Stay, if thou haſt a voyce th'art bloud and bone,
As I am, let me feele thee, elſe I'le thinke thee
A ſorcerous imaginarie ſound:
Stand me, th'art ſome Engliſh damned witch,
That from a reverend Fryer has ſtoln his ſhape
To abuſe me—ſtay—art gone? no Hagge I will not.
It ſpake ſure, told me Bruce ſhould Exit Ghoſt beckoning him to follow.
be my bane,—cannot—ſhall not,
heaven knows ſuch things onely.
That eye hath ſhot me throw, wounds me to death,
I know that face too well, but 'tis ſo gaſtly,
I'le rather with my nayles here dig my grave,
Then once more behold thee. Exit Ghoſt.
Part from me vext ſpirit, my bloud turnes to water,
I beſeech thee affright me not—it's gone.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.l: Alace Scotland to wham ſalt thou compleyne,
Alace, fra mourning wha ſall the refayne?
I thee beſeekand for him dy'd on tree,
Come not nere Bruyce, yet Bruyce ſall not hurt thee,
Alace, alace, no man can ſtand 'gainſt fate.
The dampe dew fra the heaven does gyn to faw,
I to my reſt mim gange ere the Cock crawe.

sp.speaker: Wall.
sp.l: It was my wife, what horror meete I here?
No Armour in the world can hold out feare.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: We ſtay for your direction.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Whom did you meete?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: No body.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: Saw ye nothing?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Not any thing.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: Twas my braines weakneſſe then,
I have ſeene ſtrange ſights, that anon I'le tell;
If Grimsbie we meete never more, farewell. Exit.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Ha, I am ſtrucke dumbe, oh mans ſlippery fate!
Miſchiefes that follow us at our backs we ſhunne,
And are ſtrucke downe with thoſe we dreame not on.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: I have beſide with Wallace ſherife of life,
Held private conference, who in Longſhancks name,
Who ſweares to me we ſhall have good preferment,

Beſide the promiſt gold.
Enter Wallace.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Peace, Wallace comes.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Is the Bruyce come?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: It is not yet his houre.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Who came along with you?

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: My foot-boy onely, who is tying up my horſe.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Him muſt I kill.
I'le looke if Bruce be in ſight yet— Exit.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Do.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Y'are ſad.

sp.speaker: VVa.
sp.l: My minde is ſhaken but the ſtorme is o're,
What cry is that?

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Be arm'd, Bruce with a force comes to betray thee,
From ſome villaines hand thy foot-boy is murdered.

sp.speaker: VVal.
sp.l: Murdred? Bruce ſhall repent this deed.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: So ſhalt thou, away with him.

div.stage: Enter Souldiers, knocke him downe, hurry him away in a ſound. Exeunt.
Enter Bruce muffled with a Souldier.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Helpe to diſguiſe me Souldier, in exchange
Take theſe for thine, and here's ſome gold to boot.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: If I be not hang'd, my Lord, in all my bravery,
I care not.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Phew, I warrant thee,
Seale up thy lips and eyes, thou neither ſeeſt
Nor canſt tell where I am.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: Not I my Lord.
Oh my poore wrong'd countrey, pardon me heaven,
And with a feather pluck'd from mercies wing,
Bruſh off the purple ſpots, that elſe would grow,
Like freckles on my ſoule.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: My Lord, here comes company.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Here quicke mine own agen, and get thee gone.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Sirra Souldier, ſaw'ſt thou the Earle of Huntington?

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: Huntington?

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: The Lord Bruce, I meane.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Who cals for Bruce?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Muffled up, and alone, I'le to the King. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: Do, ſirra be gone.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Whither's Percy gone? he ask'd for Bruce.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: There's great enquirie for you.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: By whom?

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: The King has a freſh command for Bruce.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: For me? he may command his Subjects.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: True, and Huntington is one.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Is none.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: No Subject?

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: None that dare oppoſe your King, Oh my impoſtum'd ſpleene,
Will flie into their faces, what command
Has England now?

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Freſh powers are to be levied,
Which Bruce of Huntington muſt leade.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: 'Gainſt whom?

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Gainſt proud Wallace, 'gainſt the Scots.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: I will not, I'm not his Butcher,
Gainſt the Scots I will not fight.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: How, will not?

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: No, will not Clifford.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: Peace.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: My Lord, I dare not,
In this laſt battell I receiv'd ſome wounds
That yet bleed inward, I will no more banquet ſtrangers
With my native bloud.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: Bruce ſpeaks not like a ſubject.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: Engliſh Edward commands not like a King,
Thrice honour'd Clifford, I'le truſt you with my boſome.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: No, you ſhall not.
My virgin honour is ſo chaſt, it ſhall not
Keepe companie with a diſquiet boſome,
Nor talke with diſcontents.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: It ſhall not, I will but,
Spare me, the ayre hath eares no more,
You ſent to me, I will but tell bold Clifford
Not a word,
My thoughts owe as much honour as their Lord.

div.stage: Enter King, North, Herefor, and followers.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: A mutinie, what noyſe is't?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Mentith, a Knight of Scotland.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: Keepe him off.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What com'ſt thou for?

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Comyn my countryman and I have brought
A jewell to your Highneſſe, which if 'twere right
As 'tis known counterfeit, 'twere worth a kingdome,
Wearied with warre, and pittying the deep wounds
Which fainting Scotland beares upon her breaſt,
And knowing that the onely ſword which gaſhes
Her tender ſides, is grip'd in Wallace hands,
I in my love to peace, and to the ſafetie
Of two great Nations, am the man that layed
Snares to entrap this monſter, that devoures
So many thouſand lives, the Rebell's tane.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: I have brought him to your Engliſh Camp,
Force would not doo't, but policie, we ſtruck the Stagge
To the ground, and thought him dead, but heaven put backe
The blow of purpoſe, hee's now come to life,
From an aſtoniſhment when we thought him dead,
To th'end the world may ſee the publique ſhame
Of an Arch-traytor.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Mentith hath wonne fame,
And honour by this act, fetch in this devill. Exit Ment.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Thou wilt have Englands thanks, but Scotlands curſe,
Thou never haſt done better, never worſe,
Damn'd Iudas to thy Country-man and friend.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Where am I?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Here with Bruce.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Bruce my Soveraigne?
My bloud is ſold, this is not Glaſco-moore,
Some villaine hath betray'd me.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Speak to your country-men, Comyn and Mentith.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Comyn and Mentith?
Something it was that made the modeſt night
Looke angry on the world, I this was it,
And this was it that cleft my fathers grave,
And rais'd him from his monumentall bed of earth
To give me gentle warning, this was it,
That made my ſtarre, when all the reſt look'd pale,
Bluſh like a fiery Meteor, can Heaven winke at this?

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: It can, it doth, and at farre greater miſchiefs.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Not of thy acting?

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Yes of mine.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Not here.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Here or in Hell.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Why then goe act them there,
Boaſt of them there, in that black Kingdome tell
That by a true ſubject a baſe Rebell fell.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Whats that?

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Your Scotch jeweller is ſlain,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: By whom?

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: By Wallace.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Heare me ſpeak King Edward.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Good my Liege heare him,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Clif. I have vow'd,
Neither to heare nor ſee him, drag him hence,
Mine eye ſhall nor be ſo compaſſionate
To view him, leaſt I pitie him: hang, draw, and quarter him.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Firſt heare me ſpeak,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Drag him hence, and let that heart, thoſe limbes,
Which were the motives to rebellious warre
Be torn aſunder, caſt upon that ground,
Which he with unkinde ſteele ſo oft did wound,
Away with him.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Farewell, to all the World,
I ha met death too often to feare him now,
Only it grieves me that I have not freed
Scotland my native ſoile from tyranny,
Bruce, thou haſt a Kingdome, loſe it not.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Stop his throat.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: I go to one too,
And on my grave, when death hath there down laid me,
Be this my Epitaph, mine own betrayes me— Exit.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: Let him have noble triall.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: He ſhall have the triall of an Arch-traitour,
Percy and Clifford take hence Bruce.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: Me hence?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You hence ſir, from this houre I ſweare,
Never to ſee thee Earle of Huntingdon,
Harke Clifford, and Northumberland, awa

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: What is King Edwards meaning?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Your head ſhal feel our meaning, ſee it diſpatch'd.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l:
You may.
Exeunt Bruce, North and Clifford.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: My honor'd Lord, although untimely death,
Hath taken hence one engine of that work,
That brought that Rebell Wallace to his end.
Seeing our Countries peace, and Englands good,
Is by his death made perfect and compleat,
I doubt not but the promiſed reward
Of full ten thouſand Crowns ſhall now remayn,
To the Survivor.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Comin, I perceive
It was reward, not love that acted it,
But you ſhall have your due, of that anon. A flouriſh.
I told thee Bruce, that thou upon thy head,
Shouldſt feele our meaning, and that all the world,
May know we value honour above conqueſt,
Having a power able to turn all Scotland
Into a Chaos, here twixt both our Armies,
Give us thy oath of fealty, and weare
Both Crown and title of thine Anceſtors.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: England is full of honour, Bruce doth bend
To thy command. They crown him.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Give him his oath of fealty,
With him thoſe Lords which are his Countrymen.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: Stand back, a Serpent ſhall not with his breath
Infect our Kingly eares, die ſlave, for he
That would betray his friend ſhall nere ſerve me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What hath Bruce done?

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: A ſacrifice of honour and revenge, no traitors hand
Shall help to lift a Crown up to my head,
Thou didſt betray, then die unpitied.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Brave Bruce, I'le love thee for this honor'd act,
Thou haſt perform'd a noble piece of juſtice:
Now ſhall the Ghoſt of Wallace ſleepe in peace,
And perfect love ſhall twixt theſe Lands increaſe.
He hath his full reward for his foule treaſon,
Drag hence the ſlave, and make him food for Crows.
The Lamp that gave Rebellion light, hath ſpent
The oile that fed it, all our ſpears are turn'd
To Palmes and Olive branches, all our ſtars
Are now made whole, peace is the balme of wars.
